conclusion: Understanding the setup with block A connected to spring B and a rope passing over a pulley to spring C.
Spring C can be pulled from position a to position b, which is 60 cm away.
Mass of block A is 2 kg and spring constant of spring B is 200 N/m.
When spring C is pulled to position b, tension in spring B equals the weight of block A.
Need to find the height block A rises and spring constant k2 of spring C.
Block A is at rest, connected to spring B, which is stretched or compressed depending on the weight of A.
Spring C is at its natural length, so no force is applied by it at this point.
Calculate the weight of block A as 19.6 N.
Determine the initial extension of spring B using force balance: x1 = 0.098 m.
Spring C is stretched by 60 cm (0.6 m) when pulled from position a to position b.
Force exerted by spring C is Fc = k2 * 0.6 m.
At new position, tension in spring B equals weight of block A: x2 = 0.098 m.
Realize that pulling spring C should affect the position of block A.
Consider displacement of block A upwards from its initial position due to force from spring C.
Force exerted by spring C is transmitted to block A via the rope.
At equilibrium, forces on block A balance: k1 * x2 + Fc = mg.
